Dual-linker metal-organic frameworks as efficient carbon dioxide conversion catalysts Xianghai Song Yuanfeng Wu Donghui Pan Jiahui Zhang Siquan Xu Lijing Gao Ruiping Wei Jin Zhang Guomin Xiao ⁎ School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Southeast University, Nanjing, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Southeast University Nanjing China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Catalytic conversion of CO2 over dual-linker MOFs. In the present work, two dual-linker metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) were prepared with metal salts, terephthalic acid and 4, 4′-bipyridine as precursors, and subsequently used for preparing cyclic carbonates from carbon dioxide and epoxides. These two MOFs were characterized by a number of techniques. The two MOFs prepared showed superior catalytic performance under solventless and co-catalyst-free conditions. In this sense, Co(tp)(bpy) achieved epichlorohydrin (ECH) conversions as high as 95.75% and chloropropylene carbonate (CPC) yields of 94.18% under optimal reaction conditions. The high activity of Co(tp)(bpy) was attributed to the co-existence of Lewis acidic and basic active sites on the catalyst derived from incompletely coordinated metal cations and uncoordinated pyridine groups, respectively. In addition, Co(tp)(bpy) maintained this high catalytic performance after five consecutive reaction cycles. A possible reaction mechanism was proposed based on the experimental results. Keywords MOFs Dual-linker Carbon dioxide Cyclic carbonates 1 Introduction The concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2), an important greenhouse gas, is increasing rapidly in the atmosphere because of the extensive combustion of fossil fuels worldwide. This increase is believed to cause originate global warming, which is associated to global climate changes [1]. This phenomenon may result in a serious threat to society [2]. A number of approaches have been developed to reduce the levels of atmospheric CO2. These approaches can be roughly divided into three main categories: (1) reduction of the CO2 produced; (2) permanent storage of CO2; and (3) usage of CO2 as a raw material [3]. Despite being an industrial waste gas, CO2 can be used as an abundant, inexpensive, non-toxic, and renewable C1 precursor [4–7]. Thus, among the three strategies indicated above, the utilization of CO2 as a feedstock for producing value-added products is a very promising route that has attracted increasing research attention [8–10]. Cyclic carbonates are considered very important CO2 derivatives owing to their wide applications (e.g., fuel additives, electrolyte solvents for ion batteries, cosmetics, personal care products, and pharmaceutical intermediates, among others) [11–13]. Over the past few decades, a series of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts have been developed to carry out the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides to cyclic carbonates [14–24]. Although some of these catalysts are highly effective and can catalyze the cycloaddition under very mild conditions [25–27], they suffer from high cost, poor reusability, and required the addition of co-catalysts. Thus, further studies on the coupling of CO2 with epoxides are still needed. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class organic–inorganic hybrid porous materials that have received increasing attention over the past few years owing to their functional and structural diversity [28–30]. The functionalities and structure of MOFs can be easily tuned by varying the organic functional groups and inorganic metal ions. Thus, the porosity (e.g., pore shape and pore volume) and the chemical properties of the MOF materials can be tailored to meet certain requirements [31]. This characteristic makes MOFs ideal candidates for gas separation/purification and heterogeneous catalysis applications [32]. MOFs have been widely used in CO2 involving applications such as capture, storage, and chemical transformation in the past few years [33–37]. MOFs have also been reported to catalyze the coupling of CO2 with epoxides (Scheme 1 ). For instance, Cu3(BTC)2 catalyzed the coupling of CO2, although the conversion of epichlorohydrin (ECH) and the selectivity towards chloropropylene carbonate (CPC) were poor [38]. To improve the catalytic performance of MOFs, quaternary ammonium salts have been usually added as co-catalysts because of their highly synergistic effect with MOFs [39]. For example, the addition of tetra-butyl ammonium bromide (TBAB) provided MOF-5, NH2-MIL-101(Al), MOF-892, BIT-C with high epoxide conversion and cyclic carbonate selectivities [40–43]. However, recycling of TBAB was hindered during the reaction process owing to the high solubility of the ammonium salt in the reaction solution. To overcome this issue, various active sites have been incorporated into the structure of the MOFs. Jun Kim et al. introduced amino groups in the structure of UIO-66 [44]. The resulting UIO-66-NH2 material was used as a CO2 coupling catalyst. Zhou et al. developed an efficient catalyst for preparing CO2-derived cyclic carbonates by incorporating quaternary ammonium salts into the structure of IRMOF-3 [45]. Despite these advances, these reactions still require the presence of a solvent (e.g., chlorobenzene) or high temperature (e.g., 140 °C). Thus, the solventless preparation of cyclic carbonates under mild conditions and in the absence of co-catalyst remains challenging. High epoxide conversions and moderate cyclic carbonate selectivities were achieved over a ZIF-8 catalyst [46]. This high catalytic performance was ascribed to the co-existence of Lewis acid (from zinc ions) and Lewis basic sites (from the imidazole groups). However, the structure of ZIF-8 collapsed during the recycling process. During the coupling of CO2 with epoxides, the unsaturated metal cations on the MOF material can act as Lewis acid sites, activating the epoxides for subsequent ring opening over co-catalysts having Lewis basic sites. In this work, we aimed to synthesize MOF materials: (i) containing both Lewis acid and Lewis basic sites in their structure; (ii) being stable during the reaction process; and (iii) recyclable. With this purpose, Co(tp)(bpy) and Zn(tp)(bpy)0.5·(DMF)(H2O)0.5 (MOF-508a) materials with both Lewis acid and Lewis basic sites (Scheme 2 ) were prepared and used for preparing cyclic carbonates from CO2. Both catalysts showed high epoxide conversion and cyclic carbonate selectivities. Moreover, Co(tp)(bpy) remained stable during the reaction and retained its structure even after five consecutive cycles. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All chemicals used in this work were commercially available and used as received without further purification. CoCl2·6H2O (AR), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (AR), terephthalic acid (99%), cyclohexene oxide (99%) and 4,4′-bipyridine were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Inc. (Shanghai, China). Allyl glycidyl ether (99%), styrene oxide (99%) were obtained from Xilong Chemical Co., Ltd. Epichlorohydrin (ECH) (99.5%), 1,2-epoxypropane (99.5%) and N,N-Dimethylformamide were supplied by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Carbon dioxide (CO2 > 99.9%) was obtained from Nanjing Special Gas Factory Co., Ltd. 2.2 Preparation of the catalysts 2.2.1 Preparation of Co(tp)(bpy) Co(tp)(bpy) was prepared according to a procedure reported elsewhere [47]. Typically, 0.71 g (3 mmol) of CoCl2·6H2O, 0.50 g (3 mmol) of terephthalic acid, 0.48 g (3.1 mmol) of 4, 4′-bipyridine, and 0.24 g (6 mmol) of NaOH were dispersed in 180 mL of deionized water. The resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature for 30 min and subsequently transferred to a 250 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclave was heated to 170 °C and kept at this temperature for 48 h. The reaction system was cooled down to room temperature, and the as-obtained solid was isolated and washed with ethanol. After drying at room temperature, dark brown crystals were obtained (0.80 g, 76%). 2.2.2 Preparation of MOF-508a MOF-508a was prepared according to a procedure reported elsewhere [48]. Typically, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.71 g, 2.36 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.39 g, 2.36 mmol), and 4, 4′-bipyridine (0.18 g, 1.18 mmol) were placed in a Teflon vessel (250 mL) containing 200 mL of DMF: ethanol mixture (1:1). The mixture was stirred at room temperature until a clear solution was obtained. The resulting solution was subsequently kept at 90 °C for 24 h. The colorless crystals formed were collected by filtration, washed with DMF and hexane, and dried in air (0.86 g, 90%). A degassing treatment at 120 °C for 12 h under reduced pressure was applied to MOF-508a to remove the guest molecules in the structure, resulting in MOF-508b. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) data of the MOFs were obtained on an Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer. The scanning was performed in the 20–75° 2θ range with a step function of 0.02 and a scanning rate of 20° min−1. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were measured by static N2 physisorption at −196 °C using a Beishide 3H-2000 analyser. Multipoint Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) was utilized to calculate the surface area. The pore size distribution was calculated based on desorption branches of the isotherms using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FT-IR) analysis was carried out on a Nicolet 5700 spectrometer. The experiment was performed over the 400–4000 cm−1 wavenumber range with KBr as a reference. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a TG209 F3 instrument. During the experimental process, the sample was heated from 30 to 660 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in N2 atmosphere. CO2/NH3 temperature programmed desorption (CO2/NH3 -TPD) was performed to evaluate the basic and acidic properties of the materials. The sample was first treated at 150 °C for one hour in helium atmosphere to eliminate the effects of adsorbed molecules. After cooling down to 50 °C, the sample was exposed to CO2/NH3 for 30 min. The sample was subsequently purged with helium for one hour to exclude the physically adsorbed gas. Finally, the sample was heated to 650 °C at a flow heating rate of 10 °C/min and the desorbed gas was detected using a thermal conductivity detector. 2.4 Catalytic activity tests The coupling of CO2 with epoxides to prepare cyclic carbonates was performed in a 100 mL stainless-steel autoclave. In a typical experiment, 5 g of ECH, and 0.05 g of the catalyst were placed in the reactor at room temperature. The reactor was subsequently purged with CO2 for three times and pressurized to the desired pressure. The system was heated to the desired temperature and maintained at this temperature. Once the reaction was finished, the reaction system was cooled to room temperature and the excess CO2 was vented slowly. The catalyst was separated by centrifugation, and the products were analyzed by gas chromatograph (GC). The products were further identified by GC coupled with mass spectrometry (GCMS, Agilent 6890) device equipped with a HP-5 capillary column (30 m × 0.32 mm). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The as-prepared MOFs were characterized by powder XRD, and the results are shown in Fig. 1 . Co(tp)(bpy) revealed four main peaks at 10.5, 15.9, 17.2, and 20.3°, characteristics of the Co(tp)(bpy) structure. The simulated powder XRD pattern of Co(tp)(bpy) was also obtained to verify the structure of the prepared material. The XRD pattern of Co(tp)(bpy) matched well with that obtained by simulation, indicating that the material was successfully prepared. The powder XRD pattern of MOF-508a was in line with those reported in the literature [48], and with the simulated profile. Thus, these two MOFs were successfully prepared. Co(tp)(bpy) and MOF-508a were subjected to N2 adsorption–desorption measurements to obtain the specific surface area and pore size distribution of both materials (Fig. 2 ). No adsorption data were obtained for Co(tp)(bpy), revealing a nonporous structure. MOF-508a exhibited a type Ⅰ adsorption isotherm (specific surface area as high as 476.45 m2/g) typical of microporous structures. In addition, MOF-508a showed a narrow pore size distribution around 2 nm, further confirming the microporous structure of this material. The FT-IR spectra of both MOFs are shown in Fig. 3 . The absorption peak at 1685 cm−1 ascribed to the carbonyl groups (CO) of terephthalic acid disappeared after coordinating with Co and Zn ions. Instead, antisymmetric stretching vibration bands ascribed to dicarboxylate groups were observed at 1609 and 1553 cm−1 [49] and 1614 and 1555 cm−1 for Co(tp)(bpy) and MOF-508a, respectively. These changes revealed that terephthalic acid was successfully coordinated with Co and Zn ions. The symmetric stretching vibration band of dicarboxylate groups were observed at 1426 and 1402 cm−1, and shifted slightly after coordinating with Co and Zn ions [50,51]. The absorption bands of 4, 4′-bipyridine at 3000 cm−1 almost disappeared for Co(tp)(bpy) and MOF-508a [52], suggesting that the reaction between 4, 4′-bipyridine and Zn/Co ions took place. The broad band of Co(tp)(bpy) and MOF-508a at 3000-3500 cm−1 was attributed to the molecular water adsorbed on the MOFs [53]. In line with XRD, FT-IR also suggested that the two MOFs were successfully prepared. The thermal stability of both materials was assessed by TGA as shown in Fig. 4 . Co(tp)(bpy) was stable up to 410 °C, since a nearly negligible weight loss was observed up to this temperature. However, a sharp weight loss of 73.36 wt% was observed in the 410–620 °C temperature range, attributed to the decomposition of Co(tp)(bpy). This profile was very similar to that observed for [NiCo(μ2-tp)(μ4-tp)(4,4′-bpy)2]n [47]. In contrast, MOF-508a showed three weight loss stages. The first (13.39 wt%, 30–118 °C) and the second (4.51 wt%, 118–266 °C) weight loss stages were ascribed to the loss of guest molecules such as H2O and DMF. The intense weight loss over the 360–600 °C temperature range was assigned to the decomposition of MOF-508a [48]. According to the TGA results, it was concluded that both MOF materials were stable before 360 °C. The CO2 coupling tests were carried out at around 100 °C, well below the decomposition temperature of these two catalysts. Thus the catalysts should remain stable during the reaction process. According to previous reports, both basic and acidic active sites are beneficial to the coupling reaction of CO2 [54,55]. The basic and acidic properties of the two MOFs were evaluated by CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD, and the results are shown in Fig. 5 . The intense peaks at 500 and 550 °C were derived from the decompositions of MOF-508a and Co(tp)(bpy). The CO2-TPD profiles of both Co(tp)(bpy) and MOF-508a revealed no CO2 desorption peaks (Fig. 5a). To confirm this result, CO2-TPD was performed at a flow heating rate of 2 °C/min. While MOF-508a showed two weak CO2 desorption peaks at 128 and 325 °C (Fig. S1), no peak was observed for Co(tp)(bpy), implying either the absence of basic sites on this catalyst or that the basic sites were too weak to adsorb CO2. The NH3-TPD profile of MOF-508a showed two moderate and one strong desorption peak at 154, 251, and 457 °C, respectively. These peaks were originated from the desorption of NH3 from weak, moderate, and strong acidic sites, respectively. This suggested the presence of numerous acidic sites on MOF-508a. In contrast, Co(tp)(bpy) showed only two small NH3 desorption peaks at 118 and 166 °C (Fig. 5b), indicating that only a few weak acidic sites were present on Co(tp)(bpy). The large amount of NH3 adsorbed on MOF-508a may be related to its high specific surface area, which increases the availability of acidic sites for NH3 adsorption. Since both catalysts showed good catalytic performance towards the coupling of CO2, both MOFs should possess basic sites. These basic sites might be too weak to adsorb CO2 at low temperature, although they could activate CO2 at high temperature. The ability for adsorbing CO2 was also investigated on both catalysts and displayed in Fig. 6 . The adsorption ability followed the trend MOF-508a > Co(tp)(bpy) ≈ 4, 4′-bipyridine. The high amount of CO2 adsorbed on by MOF-508a was attributed to its large specific surface area. Both Co(tp)(bpy) and 4, 4′-bipyridine hardly adsorbed CO2 given their non-porous structures and limited surface areas. These results were in line with the TPD analyses. Despite these results, Co(tp)(bpy) and 4,4′-bipyridine showed higher catalytic activities than MOF-508a. Thus, the catalytic performance does not seem to be related exclusively to the amount of CO2 adsorbed and other factors might also affect. 3.2 Catalytic activities 3.2.1 Catalytic performance of various catalysts The catalytic performance of the raw materials and the prepared MOFs are summarized in Table 1 . No product was obtained in the absence of catalysts (Entry 1). The yield of CPC was as low as 1.55% when terephthalic acid was used as a catalyst (Entry 2), suggesting that this compound is inactive for the coupling reaction. Interestingly, 4, 4′-bipyridine afforded a high ECH conversion of 97.51% and a CPC yield of 90.04% (Entry 3), revealing an outstanding activity for this reaction. In contrast, 4, 4′-bipyridine showed a poor selectivity towards CPC. In addition, the reusability of 4, 4′-bipyridine is problematic and needs to be solved. Thus, the 4, 4′-bipyridine-based MOFs were selected to catalyze the coupling of CO2. The two selected MOFs were active for this reaction. Co(tp)(bpy) provided an ECH conversion of 69.17% with a CPC selectivity of 98.77% (Entry 4), with minor amounts of 3-chloro-1, 2-propandiol byproduct. This byproduct may be produced by the reaction between ECH and the moisture present in the reactant or catalyst. MOF-508a showed an ECH conversion of 63.16%, slightly lower than that of Co(tp)(bpy) (Entry 5). Thus, Co(tp)(bpy) was further investigated to identify the optimal reaction parameters. 3.2.2 Optimization of the reaction conditions Since Co(tp)(bpy) showed the best catalytic performance among the catalysts studied, it was further investigated to identify the optimal reaction conditions, and the results are displayed in Fig. 7 . The first parameter investigated was the dosage of catalyst. The yield of CPC increased with the catalyst dosage (from 58.21 to 92.89% for catalyst dosage of 0.5 and 1.0 wt%, respectively). A further increase in the catalyst dosage did not increase the yield of CPC significantly (Fig. 7a). The yield of CPC also increased with temperature, from 43.24% at 80 °C to 94.18% at 100 °C A further increase in temperature showed little influence on the yield of CPC (94.11% at 120 °C, Fig. 7b). The reaction seemed to require an induction period, as indicated by the slow reaction rates within the first three hours. After this period, the reaction proceeded rapidly for the next two hours and more slowly thereafter (Fig. 7c). The yield of CPC was observed to decrease with the pressure of CO2 (93.34 and 81.69% for 0.5 and 4 MPa, respectively, Fig. 7d), in good agreement with previous reports [18,56]. However, a CO2 pressure of 0.5 MPa was not sufficient to complete the reaction, and extra CO2 was needed. Hence, the optimal reaction conditions were: 1 wt% catalyst loading, 100 °C, 1 MPa of CO2, and 7 h reaction time. 3.2.3 Catalytic performance of MOF-508a The catalytic performance of MOF-508a under the optimal reaction conditions was also investigated (Entry 2 of Table 2 ). Despite having higher specific surface area and more acidic sites compared to Co(tp)(bpy), MOF-508a showed slightly lower ECH conversions and CPC yields. A possible explanation for this phenomenon was investigated, and the results are summarized in Table 2. According to the experiments detailed above and previous literature results [48], MOF-508a contained numerous guest molecules within its structure. These guest molecules were easily removed at high temperature and reduced pressure. Thus, this material was treated at high temperature and reduced pressure to avoid the effect of the guest molecules. After removing the guest molecules, a new material MOF-508b was formed, as proved by XRD and N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm analysis (Figs. S2–S4). The resulting MOF-508b achieved ECH conversions as low as 41.58% (Entry 3), suggesting that the guest molecules played a key role in the reaction. To confirm this, when MOF-508b and the guest molecule DMF were used as the catalysts, an ECH conversion of 98.44% was achieved (Entry 4), revealing that DMF played an important role in the reaction. When DMF itself was used as the only catalyst, an ECH conversion of 75.38% was obtained (Entry 5). The above results evidenced a synergistic effect between MOF-508b and DMF. When H2O was utilized in combination with MOF-508b, an ECH conversion of 74.96% was achieved, indicating that H2O could also facilitate the reaction. However, the selectivity towards 3-chloro-1, 2-propandiol (a by-product produced by the reaction between ECH and H2O) increased to 9.99%, indicating that high H2O contents could affect negatively to the selectivity of CPC. In addition, after the reaction, only a small amount of MOF-508a was recovered, indicating that this material was not stable under reaction conditions used herein. In contrast, Co(tp)(bpy) remained nearly unchanged after the reaction. Hence, the slightly lower catalytic performance of MOF-508a as compared to Co(tp)(bpy) may result from the loss of guest molecules and the decomposition of the catalyst. 3.2.4 Catalytic activity of Co(tp)(bpy) for various epoxides The catalytic performance of Co(tp)(bpy) towards the production of cyclic carbonates other than CPC was also investigated to explore potential applications. As shown in Table 3 , Co(tp)(bpy) showed good catalytic performance for the production of most terminal cyclic carbonates. Thus, the yields of propylene carbonate, 1, 2-butylene carbonate, allyloxymethyl-1, 3-dioxolan-2-one, 4-phenyl-1, 3-dioxolan-2-one were all above 90% (Entries 2–5), revealing the wide potential applications of this catalyst. However, regarding internal epoxides, Co(tp)(bpy) showed poor yields of cyclic carbonates. For instance, the yield of cyclohexene carbonate was as low as 6.85% over Co(tp)(bpy) (Entry 6). This poor conversion of cyclohexene oxide may be related to the larger steric hindrance of the epoxy group, hindering the nucleophilic attack of the nucleophilic agent to the epoxide. 3.2.5 Reusability of the catalyst The reusability of a heterogeneous catalyst is of outmost importance when selecting a catalyst. The reusability of Co(tp)(bpy) was evaluated and the result is displayed in Fig. 8 . The catalytic performance of Co(tp)(bpy) remained nearly unchanged for the first three cycles. Although the yield of CPC decreased slightly during the fourth run, a CPC yield as high as 80.12% was achieved after the fifth cycle, indicating the good stability of this catalyst during the coupling of CO2. The characterization of the recovered Co(tp)(bpy) is summarized in Fig. 9 . The crystal structure of the material was basically maintained after five reaction cycles, as revealed by XRD (Fig. 9a). These results indicated that the catalyst was very stable during the reaction. Co(tp)(bpy)-R5 showed a similar FT-IR spectrum as compared to Co(tp)(bpy) (Fig. 9b). Only a sharp absorption band at 1796 cm−1 and a broad absorption band at 1044–1165 cm−1 were observed for Co(tp)(bpy)-R5, and these bands were absent for Co(tp)(bpy). The absorption bands at 1796 and 1044–1165 cm-1 were assigned to the CO and CO stretching vibrations of the adsorbed cyclic carbonates, respectively [57]. The characterization of the recovered catalyst suggested that the catalyst was stable under reaction conditions, in line with the TG results. With the aim to explain the loss of catalytic performance, catalyst leaching tests were performed (Table 4 ). After the first cycle, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation. The filtrate was mixed with ECH and the resulting mixture was allowed to react at the same conditions of a typical run. The conversion of ECH increased from 38.65 to 58.12% after the reaction, suggesting the presence of some active components in the filtrate. Thus, the decrease in catalytic performance was originated from leaching phenomena. 3.2.6 Possible reaction mechanism Basic and acidic sites have been reported to synergistically catalyze the coupling of CO2 with epoxides [21,58–60]. During the reaction, basic sites can activate CO2, while acidic sites could facilitate ring opening of epoxides by the activation of the epoxides. According to previous reports, the unsaturated metal cations on MOFs could serve as Lewis acidic active sites [61,62]. According to the experimental results, 4, 4′-bipyridine was highly active towards this reaction. Considering previous works, the experimental results, and the characteristic information, a possible reaction mechanism was proposed (Scheme 3 ). The unsaturated metal cations and the uncoordinated pyridine groups can serve as Lewis acidic and basic active sites, respectively. During the coupling reaction, the unsaturated metal cations interact first with the O atom of the epoxides to activate the epoxy ring. The N atoms of the pyridine groups coordinate reversibly with CO2, forming a carbamate salt (Intermediate Ⅰ). Then, the carbamate nucleophilic attacks the less sterically hindered C atom of the activated epoxide to afford intermediate Ⅱ. Finally, the intermediate Ⅱ undergoes intramolecular nucleophilic substitution to give the cyclic carbonate product, and the catalyst is regenerated. 4 Conclusions In summary, two MOFs (Co(tp)(bpy) and MOF-508a) were prepared and used as catalysts in the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides. Both materials presented high catalytic performance towards the reaction in solventless and co-catalyst-free conditions. The guest molecules within the structure of MOF-508a played a key role in the reaction process. The catalytic activity of Co(tp)(bpy) was produced by the unsaturated metal cations and the uncoordinated pyridine groups. Co(tp)(bpy) was highly stable and recyclable, and CPC yields as high as 80.12% were achieved even after five consecutive reaction cycles. Moreover, Co(tp)(bpy) could be also used to produce a wide variety of cyclic carbonates, holds great potential in CO2 chemical fixation applications leading to valuable products. coredata.dc:description: In the present work, two dual-linker metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) were prepared with metal salts, terephthalic acid and 4, 4′-bipyridine as precursors, and subsequently used for preparing cyclic carbonates from carbon dioxide and epoxides. These two MOFs were characterized by a number of techniques. The two MOFs prepared showed superior catalytic performance under solventless and co-catalyst-free conditions. In this sense, Co(tp)(bpy) achieved epichlorohydrin (ECH) conversions as high as 95.75% and chloropropylene carbonate (CPC) yields of 94.18% under optimal reaction conditions. The high activity of Co(tp)(bpy) was attributed to the co-existence of Lewis acidic and basic active sites on the catalyst derived from incompletely coordinated metal cations and uncoordinated pyridine groups, respectively. In addition, Co(tp)(bpy) maintained this high catalytic performance after five consecutive reaction cycles. A possible reaction mechanism was proposed based on the experimental results.
coredata.dc:title: Dual-linker metal-organic frameworks as efficient carbon dioxide conversion catalysts
